item.title: My bucket list
item.description:
Everyone needs to have one. I will strike-off the items that I have completed. Also, this keeps a check on the progress I make year after the year.

  • Learn to drive a car
  • Go on a long drive
  • Learn Swift
  • Learn Ruby on Rails
  • Become a dependable photographer
  • Learn to
item.dc:creator: Sasi kiran Malladi
item.content:encoded:
Everyone needs to have one. I will strike-off the items that I have completed. Also, this keeps a check on the progress I make year after the year.

  • Learn to drive a car
  • Go on a long drive
  • Learn Swift
  • Learn Ruby on Rails
  • Become a dependable photographer
  • Learn to cook my favourite recipes
  • Be more social
  • Finish writing a short story
  • Give a presentation to 20+ people
  • Buy an iPhone, iPad, Macbook Pro and AppleTV
  • Adopt a pet
  • Cook for the wife
  • Sponsor food / education for the less unfortunate
  • Spend few days somewhere, far away from technology
  • Climb a mountain
  • Compile a holiday / vacation video
  • Attend a music concert
  • Attend WWDC in San Francisco
  • Drive a luxury car
  • Visit New York
  • Visit Apple headquarters in Cupertino
  • Visit Switzerland
  • Author a book
  • Buy a house

item.description:
I turned 30 today. The following is a "Previously, on Sasi's life..." explained in a 30 second time-lapse mode. Grab some popcorn, OK?

  • Born
  • Crawled
  • Walked
  • Had stitches on my forehead
  • Lost my baby teeth
  • Went to elementary school
  • Made good friends at school
  • Got good at studies
  • Went to
item.dc:creator: Sasi kiran Malladi
item.content:encoded:
I turned 30 today. The following is a "Previously, on Sasi's life..." explained in a 30 second time-lapse mode. Grab some popcorn, OK?

  • Born
  • Crawled
  • Walked
  • Had stitches on my forehead
  • Lost my baby teeth
  • Went to elementary school
  • Made good friends at school
  • Got good at studies
  • Went to high school
  • Got eye sight
  • Grandma gifted me a bicycle
  • Learned playing veena
  • Sold off my bicycle
  • Played cricket
  • Played video games
  • Lost my cricket bat
  • Learned BASIC
  • Discovered Internet
  • Went to Intermediate college
  • Made good friends at the college
  • Grandma gifted me a PC
  • Went to an engineering college
  • Made good friends at the college
  • Learned C and Java as part of the curriculum
  • Taught C++ myself
  • Started Game programming
  • Wrote a software rasteriser in C++
  • Made art using Bryce and Poser
  • Upgraded and assembled my PC
  • Was thrilled to see my posts appear in a popular IT magazine
  • Switched to Linux
  • Spent way too much time switching between SUSE and Ubuntu
  • Switched back to Windows
  • Taught Photoshop myself
  • Designed a Mac OS look alike desktop theme for Windows
  • Joined MSIT
  • Quit MSIT
  • Started working as a C programmer
  • Quit my first job
  • Had to live in hospitals when both mom and grandma didn’t do well
  • Learned to cook
  • Joined 9atoms as a C programmer
  • Switched to a Mac
  • Learned Objective-C
  • Made my first iOS app
  • Made good friends at 9atoms
  • Worked on a game at Sierra Atlantic briefly as an iOS Consultant
  • Switched back to 9atoms, got promoted as a senior engineer
  • Made several iOS apps
  • Joined a car driving course; learned nothing
  • Purchased my first car, a Volkswagen.
  • Friends taught me car driving; still learned nothing
  • Got my car a dent
  • Lost my grandma
  • Got myself an iPhone
  • Made WeatherNeue
  • Joined PurpleTalk as a Technical Lead
  • Worked on interesting apps
  • Made good friends at PurpleTalk
  • Got bitten by the shutterbug; purchased a Sony α DSLR
  • Met the girl I would marry
  • Got engaged
  • Finally learned to drive; thanks to the long distance from my home to my fiancé’s
  • Got married
  • Went to Thailand for vacation
  • Came back to Hyderabad
  • Wife moved in
  • Brought home Mickey, our adorable lhasa apso puppy
  • Had a memorable the-first-birthday-after-being-married
  • Had a memorable first anniversary
  • Tasted wine
  • Taught myself Rails and Swift
  • Turned 30

Here’s to another 30.

item.title: Minority Report
item.description: How Minority Report rightly predicted the future that we are in today!
item.dc:creator: Sasi kiran Malladi
item.content:encoded:
When Minority Report came in 2002, it had ultra-thin touch screens, gestures: swiping, pinch to zoom, Kinect / leap motion, Siri / Google Now like AI assistants, wearable computer gadgets like the  watch / Google Glass, self driving cars etc. Today, in 2014, we live in a world where all of that fantasized future we once had, is actually a reality.

I’m not really a Spielberg fan but I wonder whether he actually foresaw that the future would be something like this, or was this a purely coincidence and part of his researched script? If Spielberg did actually predict it right, well that’s really brilliant! I would want him to make Minority Report 2 as well, so that we can have a peek into our future once again.
I’ve seen other sci-fi movie directors, who took way too much liberty and introduced concepts like teleportation, time travel etc. I have a feeling that these things would remain a human fantasy for a long time and may not see the light.

There are also movies such as Aditya 369 or the very recent Oblivion, where after an apocalypse, the survivors would be seen wearing a silver colored pinstripe jump suit with boots! Actually, Jerry Seinfeld made a joke on this.
